rev.diff:
Line 25: Line 25:
== Background ==
== Background ==
  +
=== Mubarak's presidency ===
  +
President [[Hosni Mubarak]] has headed Egypt's government since the 1981 assassination of President [[Anwar Sadat]] by radical islamists. Mubarak himself was wounded during the assassination. His government has been criticised in the media. His [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|support of peace negotiations]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict]] has made him an ally of the West,<ref name="Hosni Mubarak"/> with Egypt receiving over [[US$]]1.3 billion in annual aid from the United States.<ref>{{cite web | title = Background Note: Egypt | publisher = [[United States Department of State]] | date =10 November 2010 | url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm | accessdate = 28 January 2011}}</ref> His government is also noted for its crackdown on Islamic militants.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> As a result, the initial reactions to Hosni Mubarak's abuses by the U.S. were muted.<ref>{{cite web|author=Murphy, Dan|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0126/The-US-response-to-Egypt-s-protests |title=The US Response to Egypt's Protests — 'Not Much' Probably Sums It Up Best |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
[[File:Day of Anger shoe sign.jpg|thumb|Demonstrator holding a sign depicting [[Shoeing|a shoe]] with "Jan 25" written inside it flying at Mubarak's face]]
  +
=== Emergency law ===
=== Emergency law ===
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|left|[[Paramilitary]] [[riot police]] of the [[Central Security Forces]] deployed during the 25 January protest]]
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|left|[[Paramilitary]] [[riot police]] of the [[Central Security Forces]] deployed during the 25 January protest]]
Line 30: Line 35:
The Mubarak government has used the reason of [[terrorism]] to continue extending emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008"/> and has claimed that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo parliamentary elections, confiscate the group's main financiers' possessions, and detain group figureheads—actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{cite book |last= Caraley |first= Demetrios |title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy |publisher= [[Academy of Political Science]] |year= 2004 |month= April |isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> Pro-democracy advocates in Egypt argue that this goes against the principles of [[democracy]], which include a citizen's [[right to a fair trial]] and their [[Suffrage|right to vote]] for whichever candidate or party they choose. Human rights organisations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial,<ref>{{cite web|last=Amnesty International|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref> and that in the 1990s the number of detainees was over 20,000.<ref name="eohr2008"/><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=R. Clemente Holder|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|publisher=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=August 1994|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
The Mubarak government has used the reason of [[terrorism]] to continue extending emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008"/> and has claimed that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo parliamentary elections, confiscate the group's main financiers' possessions, and detain group figureheads—actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{cite book |last= Caraley |first= Demetrios |title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy |publisher= [[Academy of Political Science]] |year= 2004 |month= April |isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> Pro-democracy advocates in Egypt argue that this goes against the principles of [[democracy]], which include a citizen's [[right to a fair trial]] and their [[Suffrage|right to vote]] for whichever candidate or party they choose. Human rights organisations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial,<ref>{{cite web|last=Amnesty International|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref> and that in the 1990s the number of detainees was over 20,000.<ref name="eohr2008"/><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=R. Clemente Holder|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|publisher=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=August 1994|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
â   â
=== Mubarak's presidency ===
  â
President [[Hosni Mubarak]] has headed Egypt's government since the 1981 assassination of President [[Anwar Sadat]] by radical islamists. Mubarak himself was wounded during the assassination. His government has been criticised in the media. His [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|support of peace negotiations]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict]] has made him an ally of the West,<ref name="Hosni Mubarak"/> with Egypt receiving over [[US$]]1.3 billion in annual aid from the United States.<ref>{{cite web | title = Background Note: Egypt | publisher = [[United States Department of State]] | date =10 November 2010 | url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm | accessdate = 28 January 2011}}</ref> His government is also noted for its crackdown on Islamic militants.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> As a result, the initial reactions to Hosni Mubarak's abuses by the U.S. were muted.<ref>{{cite web|author=Murphy, Dan|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0126/The-US-response-to-Egypt-s-protests |title=The US Response to Egypt's Protests — 'Not Much' Probably Sums It Up Best |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
